Watching this video makes me think you are the perfect person to ask this question. And let me just say, it may be a really dumb question that I just completely overlooked the answer to but I can’t seem to find one.
So, star explodes creating all the elements that eventually come together as a planet. All of the radioactive isotopes are presumably made during this stellar explosion. So, planet forms from this space dust with all of the isotopes within the dust and makes the compositions of the planet.

So, my question, why is there any difference between the amounts of isotopes anywhere on a planet?
Shouldn’t the age of all rock be the same age as the space dust it was made from?

Again, maybe it’s a supper dumb question but my understanding is that there is not really any new isotope formation so when we radiometrically date rocks there was kind of a fixed concentration at the starting point which is why the dating is reliable. I feel like I’m missing something, can you help?

The biblical account cannot be used as a metaphor for evolution. Everything is in the wrong order. The earth (day 1) was created before the stars/planets (day 4). Also, plants (day 3) were before the sun (day 4). Birds (day 5) were created before land animals, including reptiles and dinosaurs (day 6). Man wad created on day 6, not day 7. In addition the Hebrew word "yom" cannot be translated as anything other than a 24 hour day in this context. Anywhere that "yom" occurs with a number, or the word evening, or morning, it means a literal day. You can check Hebrew lexicons for this. In Genesis 1, every time "yom" appear, it has evening, morning, and a number. It must be literal days. Evolution and the Bible do not mix. If you are trying to argue against the existence of God, of course you will try to add in more time so maybe just maybe! Life could have formed by chance. But we see absolutely no processes by which this could have happened. (Yes, I can back that up, but this post is already long.) How do you explain see fossils on top of Mt Everest without the flood? How did the same rock layers form across the whole earth without a global flood? How did rock layers that took millions of years to form get bent without breaking? If you really go in with an open mind and test the conclusions , they don't make sense.

Principia: depends in how linguists hypothesize about the pronunciation of Latin. Some believe that the system of ‘hard consonant sounds before dark vowels’ and therefore soft ones before light vowels, as existing in Italian and French, was already present in Latin. Meaning: prinz/cipia is not totally ruled out. :)

The pronunciation of "principia" really depends on which contextual and regional tradition of pronouncing Latin you decide to go with. In Classical Latin, the <c> was most certainly pronounced /k/, but by the time of Vulgar Latin the sound had become palatalised before front vowels. In Ecclesiastical Latin, for example, it's pronounced /t͡ʃ/ (as in the <ch> in English "chair"), which is also the pronunciation used in Italian and Romanian pronunciations of the letter in their respective traditions of New Latin, while English an French pronounce it as /s/, thus "prin/s/ipia" as opposed to "prin/k/ipia".

Neither pronunciation is more correct than the other, as long as it's consistent, e.g. if you use prin/s/ipia, following English New Latin, then the <æ> in "philosophiæ" should be pronounced /eɪ/ (as in the <ay> of "day"), but if you use prin/k/ipia, following Classical Latin, then <æ> should be pronounced /aɪ/ (as in "eye").
